title: Map the data ecosystem (steps 2, 3, 4)
body:
Data ecosystems consist of the organisations, communities and people that create and benefit from the value created by the data flowing through our data infrastructure. Before publishing anonymised data it is important to map your own data ecosystem. This can help your organisation identify the key data stewards and users within your ecosystem, the relationships between them and the different roles they play. 

This module explains:

  • What is a data ecosystem
  • Why is it important for anonymisation
  • How to construct your data ecosystem map

title: Sample Ethics Canvas Questions
instruction: Below is a sample of some of the the Data Ethics Canvas

_items.title: Sharing data with other organisations
_items.body: Are you going to be sharing data with other organisations? If so, who? Are you planning to publish any of the data? Under what conditions?

_items.title: Your reasons for using this data
_items.body: What is your primary purpose for collecting and using data in this project? What are the main use case/s, and your business model? Are you making things better for society? How? For whom?

_items.title: Positive effects on people
_items.body: Which individuals, groups, demographics or organisations will be positively affected by this project? How will they be positively affected? How are you measuring and communicating positive impact?

_items.title: Openness and transparency
_items.body: How open can you be about this project? Could you publish your methodology, metadata, datasets, code or impact measurements? Can you ask peers to give feedback on the project? How will you communicate about it internally?

_items.title: Reviews and iterations
_items.body: How will ongoing issues related to data ethics be measured, monitored, discussed, and actioned?

_items.title: GDPR
_items.body: The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) came into force in May 2018 and governs the processing of personal data the free movement of personal data for within the European Union and for EU citizens generally. Anonymised data is not considered in scope for GDPR, but personal data before anonymisation is.

_graphic.attribution: London Market Group [All rights reserved]

_items.title: GDPR and national legislation
_items.body: The application of GDPR varies from one country to another: in the UK, the 2018 Data Protection Act implements and extends GDPR.

_graphic.attribution: London Market Group [All rights reserved]

_items.title: Talk to your DPO and legal team
_items.body: Most organisations will be required by GDPR to appoint a Data Protection Officer. Your DPO may be able to help you understand and navigate your legal context and requirements. If in doubt, talk to your legal team.

title: The Data Spectrum
body:
The ODI’s Data Spectrum describes the different levels at which data be closed or open. It ranges from closed, highly restricted-access, data to open data that can be accessed and used by anyone for any purpose. 

The Data Spectrum can be used to think about the level of anonymisation needed for the project. The more open (and further to the right) the data is on the spectrum, the greater the level of anonymisation will need to be applied to the data. If the data has group-based access then we have a better idea of who is using it, what the re-identification risks are and what are the uses of the data. However, in open data with many more users, the risks become greater and we’ll need to increase the anonymisation applied to the data.

_items.title: Data controllers and processors
_items.body:
GDPR and other regulations make an important distinction between data controller, the actors(s) determining the manner in which, and the purposes for which, the data are processed, and data processors, who processes the data on behalf of the data controller. Overall responsibility for the data lies with the data controllers, while data processors are mostly held accountable through contract and agreements. 

More info at the ICO

_graphic.attribution: London Market Group [All rights reserved]

_items.title: Use your data ecosystem map
_items.body: Data protection legislation will largely concern itself with data flows (including how the data came to be under your stewardship) and actors (data subjects, data controllers and data processors). The data ecosystem map you created in earlier steps should give you a good picture of both.

_graphic.attribution: London Market Group [All rights reserved]

title: Why is Data Ecosystem Mapping important?
displayTitle: Why is Data Ecosystem Mapping important?
body:
Data ecosystem maps can make it easier to explain the ecosystems that exist around products and services. They are particularly useful when contexts are complex, not well understood or not yet fully developed. 

When finished, the map is valuable as a communication tool to support engagement across the data ecosystem. In addition, there is value to be gained from the process of drawing it. Mapping requires you to consider different actors, relationships and ideas in the system, and can generate useful insights and talking points. 

In the context of anonymisation, it is possible to build upon a data ecosystem map to identify where in your ecosystem anonymisation processes will occur and where data will exist in anonymised and non-anonymised states. This can further help your organisation think about potential threats and benefits to the organisations, communities and people within your ecosystem.

title: Implement and iterate
body: Having selected your chosen methods, you should implement them. You may need to iterate between risk assessment and control to balance risk with data utility.

title: Data Protection Impact Assessment
body:
The ICO defines a Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA) as a process to help you identify and minimise the data protection risks of a project. You must do a DPIA for processing that is likely to result in a high risk to individuals.

(Use image?: https://ico.org.uk/media/2258436/dpia1.png) 

You do not have to create your DPIA process from scratch. The ICO offers guidance and templates, and you may find examples of how others in your sector or domain have done it.

Examples in:

  • Academia: Donor research using public information 
  • Public Sector: Community Wellbeing Centre (Local council) 
  • Third Sector: National Neonatal Audit Programme (UK Charity)

title: What is a use case?
body:
A use case is a method to describe who will be using your system and what they will be using it for. It identifies typical users, what they’re trying to achieve, what environments they’ll be in and what systems they’ll use. Creating use cases helps keep users goals as a primary focus when designing a system.

For anonymisation, your use cases provide context on how to release your data and what form the data should take. If you understand that some users want access to a particular variable you consider risky, you may need to restrict who has access to that data. To meet your obligations to release safe, useful data you may also share it with a wider audience under a different licence by restricting a lot of the detail.

For example the Wealth and Asset Survey looks at personal financial information. These variables are usually anonymised or even omitted. But in this case they are the core variables, so the anonymisation methods focus on other information like demographics.

See also: UK Government design principles.

_graphic.attribution: London Market Group [All rights reserved]

title: How to build your Data Ecosystem Map

_items.title: Identify the main categories of actors in the ecosystem
_items.body: Before beginning the process of constructing your map, it can be helpful to define a list of actors and data flows within your ecosystem. Common roles include: data stewards, regulators, intermediaries, creators (or resusers of data), beneficiaries and policymakers.

_items.title: Map the data flows between actors
_items.body: Once you have identified the main actors in your ecosystem, you can begin drawing the ecosystem on a whiteboard or on post-it notes. Starting with a single organisation you can draw lines and arrows between actors to represent the various data flows within the system. It is often helpful to start with the area of the ecosystem that you know best and to expand out from there. As you fill out your ecosystem, be careful to identify organisations performing anonymisation processes and to differentiate between arrows representing anonymised data versus non-anonymised data.

_items.title: Map the exchanges of tangible and intangible value
_items.body: After mapping the data flows between actors you can then draw lines and arrows to represent any exchanges of tangible and intangible value within the system. Examples of exchanges of tangible value include physical goods, money, services provided and any charges for those services. Common examples of intangible value include exchanges of knowledge, feedback, insights, support or policy advice.

_items.title: Identify any potential benefits or threats to actors within the system
_items.body: Now that you have a working map of the various actors in your ecosystem, the data flows and the tangible and intangible value exchanged between actors you can use the map to identify [vulnerabilities, bottlenecks or security threats] and [guide conversations] about potential benefits and harms to the organisations, communities and people within your ecosystem.
_items.strapline: Identify any potential benefits or threats to actors within the system

title: The Data Ethics Canvas
body: The ODI’s Data Ethics Canvas is designed to help identify potential ethical issues associated with a data project or activity. This helps the people anonymising and opening the data to have early discussions beyond basic legal compliance and think about the moral implications of holding or withholding all or certain parts of the data.

title: Map the legal issues (step 5)
body:
Legislation and regulation can impede, allow or even impel the flow of data. It is crucial to understand the legal context and obligations before proceeding any further. 

This module explains:

  • What are the legal issues to consider
  • Data Protection Impact Assessments
  • What next

title: What is a Data Ecosystem Map?
displayTitle: What is a Data Ecosystem Map?
body: A data ecosystem map illustrates the value exchanges in an ecosystem. Drawing on ideas from rich picturing, systems thinking and value network analysis, data ecosystem mapping can help your organisation create a visual map that [illustrates] how data is being accessed, used and shared by a variety of organisations.

title: Some user research methods
body: Below is just a small sample of user research methods that exist. Which ones to use can depend on the type of project, resources available or type of users. See more at usability.gov user research methods.

_items.title: User Interviews
_items.body: One-on-one interviews with users to understand their particular needs. These usually involve transcribing the interviews and finding important patterns among the multiple interviews. These are usually conducted at the beginning of project to get early insights in to the users and what they hope to achieve with the product.

_items.title: User Personas
_items.body: These are fictional characters representing a particular group of users who are similar in attitudes, goals and behaviours. In creating good user personas, you hope to increase empathy and understanding of each group’s needs and design your system accordingly.

_items.title: Usability testing
_items.body: Users are asked to complete certain tasks while being observed by a researcher. The researcher notes whether the tasks can be completed easily and if there was any confusion performing them. For anonymisation, you could ask some of the following. Iis the dataset clearly presented, accessible, and well-described? Do they understand the difference between the original data and the de-identified data and how utility may be affected? Can users still gather the insights they are looking for?
